messages.content: Write an email asking a colleague to make an introduction to Lumen, an energy finance company, to invite them to speak on a fireside chat event on green financethat I am hosting for Stanford Climate Week. Include information about Stanford Climate Week and the event details.

Hi Shawn,

 Stanford Climate Week is hosting a fireside chat on reimagining climate finance during the week of October 20th. We'd love to invite Lumen to join alongside Crux's CEO (who has confirmed) to discuss the future of funding green solutions. If there’s interest and availability, please let me know. More about Stanford Climate Week: https://www.stanfordclimateweek.com/

 Thanks for your help, and let me know if I can answer any questions!

 Warmly, Eyrin
Reply to an email asking for potential times to meet this week for a quick chat/interview. I work in pacific time.

Hi Eric, Thank you so much for reaching out — I would absolutely love to chat. Do any of these times work for you (PT)?

 Tuesday, Oct 14: 10 am - 12 pm, 2 - 3 pm

 Wednesday, Oct 15: 4:30 - 6 pm

 Thursday, Oct 16: 10 am - 12 pm, 1 - 3 pm

 Friday, Oct 17: 1:30 - 4:30 pm

 Looking forward to connecting! Let me know if I can answer any questions in the meantime; I'm happy to send more info about myself.

 Warmly, Eyrin

Write an email reaching out a professor asking to join his research lab / find a new opportunity. Pitch my experience and strengths, which include my studies in AI and Earth Systems, my work in computer vision at ICEYE, and my work in the Westly Group on AI and compute infrastructure market research.

Dear Professor Burke,

 My name is Eyrin, and I'm a Stanford junior studying SymSys/AI and Earth Systems. I'm writing to ask about research opportunities in your group focused on climate applications.

 This past summer at ICEYE, I built computer vision algorithms to automatically detect features in and co-register SAR satellite imagery. I also laid the framework for fine-tuning foundational vision models to improve segmentation capabilities but did not have time to finish the project before my internship ended (attaching SAR Algorithms PDF for more context).

 I am deeply interested in your work applying ML to climate problems -- especially your work utilizing satellite imagery to promote sustainable development + assess livelihood impact of electricity access. In fact, my first foray into research was a project using NASA data to optimize disaster response logistics. I would greatly appreciate discussing potential research opportunities within your group!

 Warmly, Eyrin

Write an email reaching out to a professional in the field of eningeering and energy asking for an informational coffee chat. Include information about my work in computer vision at ICEYE and my work in the Westly Group on AI and compute infrastructure market research.

Hi Takao,

 My name is Eyrin, and I'm a Stanford junior studying AI and Earth Systems. I'm reaching out because I would love to learn more about your journey and work at Crusoe, which in my opinion has one of the most ingenious solutions to aligning computing and sustainability goals.

 A quick bit of context on me: I love deep tech software and spent this summer building computer vision algorithms for satellite imagery at ICEYE. Through my work with the Westly Group on AI and compute infrastructure market research, I got deeply interested in the intersection of energy and computing (putting together events about this for Stanford Climate Week right now).

 Would you be open to a 20-minute chat in the next few weeks? I'd be grateful for the chance to pick your brain.

 Warmly, Eyrin

Write an email reaching out to a professional in the field of eningeering management asking for an informational coffee chat. Include the fact that I worked on the internal "pirate ship" at ICEYE, I enjoy bringing people together to bring a product from nothing to something, and I thrive with ambiguous, open-ended challenges.

Hi Audrey!,

 My name is Eyrin, and I'm a junior at Stanford studying CS and Earth Systems. This past summer, I worked on the internal "pirate ship" at ICEYE and learned 1) I enjoy bringing people together to bring a product from nothing to something and 2) I thrive with ambiguous, open-ended challenges (attaching my resume for more context). As a result, I thought Apple's EPM internship might be a great way to best utilize my strengths. 

 Would you have 20 minutes in the next few weeks to chat? I'd love to learn more about your experience.

 Warmly, Eyrin
Write an email connecting a Venture Capitalist, Jo, to a founder of a startup in the field of semiconductor design, Nils.

Hi Jo, Nils;

 Jo, meet Nils, a brilliant engineer reinventing chips as we know them. He and the team are beginning to think about raising and would love to talk to Lux.

 Nils, meet Jo, a fantastic investor at Lux Capital who is happy to loop you in.

 You both have context, so I'll leave you to connect.

 Warmly, Eyrin

Write an email connecting a fellow student in finance, Amy Wang, to a finance recruiter at a top finance firm, Leslie Foard. Mention that Amy recently learned that the investment banking group she was going to intern with, Barclays' Sponsors in LA, is being shut down.

Hello,

 Leslie, meet Amy Wang, a rockstar Stanford undergraduate with a deep interest in finance. As I mentioned, she unfortunately recently learned that the investment banking group she was going to intern with, Barclays' Sponsors in LA, is being shut down. I'm attaching her resume in this email.

 Amy, meet Leslie Foard, Principal at Alpine Investors and a Stanford alumna! She is one of the kindest, sincerest people I have ever met in my foray into finance/recruiting. You both have context, so I'll leave you to connect.

 Warmly, Eyrin

Reply to an email with a lot of information details (like onboarding information) where I must confirm that I've read and understood the information. I must specifically confirm the start date of my internship, which is Monday, June 23rd. Ask about what days I will be in-person in the office and if I need to bring anything specific.

Hi Michael,

 Thank you so much for setting this up. I have looked through the onboarding document + both of your onboarding emails, and everything looks great to me. Confirming that I will be in the office Monday, June 23rd, but I am also flexible if it is easier for the team for me to come in on Tuesday — I might be a little less jet-lagged then too. Either way, I am so excited to get started!

 Do you know which days I will be in-person in the office? Is there anything specific I should bring with me to the office (i.e. ID/passport, etc)?

 Warmly, Eyrin

Write an email asking colleagues, Ava and Maddie, if they would be interested in being introduced to a new colleague and potential founder to invest in who is building an enhanced rock weathering company called ZeroEx. I'm not sure if they would be interested in investing, but I think they might be interested in chatting with them.

Hi Ava and Maddie,

 Hope you all are doing well! I just spoke met with the founders of an enhanced rock weathering company called ZeroEx — see information below. They have the best approach to carbon removal measurement I've heard of to date (solving the carbon credits issue) and a strong vision. Great traction and currently expanding to the US. 

 Although they might not be a direct fit for GGRF, I thought you all might be interested in chatting with them. I think they're solving a truly hard problem in a really interesting way.

 Let me know if you'd be open to an intro!

 Warmly, Eyrin

Write an email reaching out to a professional and leader in the energy space, Alexander, to ask for a coffee chat. Include the fact that I've been deeply interested in America's electric grid recently and stumbled across Tapestry. Further research led me to Bellwether and Chorus, both of which were directionally similar to work I've done and intellectually similar to the type of work I love.

Hi Alexander,

 My name is Eyrin and I'm a junior at Stanford studying AI and Earth Systems. I'm reaching out because I would love to learn more about what you do at Google X.

 I've been deeply interested in America's electric grid recently and stumbled across Tapestry. Further research led me to Bellwether and Chorus, both of which were directionally similar to work I've done and intellectually similar to the type of work I love — attaching my resume for more context. To be frank, I think Google X is home to some of the coolest frontier innovations at the moment (especially related to energy and the planet), and I think you might have the coolest job within Google X.

 Would you be open to a 20-minute chat in the next few weeks? I'd be grateful for the chance to learn more about your journey and your work.

 Warmly, Eyrin
